H0.text: A nucleus is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H1.text: A molecule is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H2.text: An element is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H3.text: An atom is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

A4.text: Earlier definitions were less precise, defining molecules as the smallest particles of pure chemical substances that still retain their composition and chemical properties.

A5.text: No typical molecule can be defined for salts nor for covalent crystals, although these are often composed of repeating unit cells that extend either in a plane, e.g. graphene; or three-dimensionally e.g.

A6.text: A molecule is the smallest unit of a substance that still carries all the physical and chemical properties of that substance.
